S5.T1.caption:
Table I: Forward Propagation Costs for Convolutional Layer
(unit: micro-second): Impact of Input Size.
Settings: sâ€‹tâ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹e=2ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’2stride=2, fâ€‹iâ€‹lâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹zâ€‹e=8Ã—8ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ_ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’88filter\_size=8\times 8, and fâ€‹iâ€‹lâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹_â€‹nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹bâ€‹eâ€‹r=16ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ_ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ16filter\_number=16.
S5.T1.table:
input size original fwd SGX fwd new fwd selective test
16Ã—\times16 124 145 303 35
32Ã—\times32 818 865 1265 41
64Ã—\times64 3990 4161 5242 59
128Ã—\times128 17705 18382 21065 118
256Ã—\times256 74196 76868 84815 360
references:
TableÂ I shows the costs of the schemes
for the forward propagation through a convolutional layer,
as the input size varies.
The original schemeâ€™s cost is denoted as original fwd and
the full-SGX schemeâ€™s cost is denoted as SGX fwd.
For our proposed scheme,
the cost incurred at the untrusted worker is dentoed as new fwd
and the cost for selective test incurred at the SGX enclave is denoted as selective test.
All the costs are measured as the computation latency in the unit of micro-second.
Here, 16 filters each of size 8Ã—\times8 are used and the stride is set to 2.

As we can see from TableÂ I,
the cost of the original scheme is slightly lower than the full-SGX scheme
due to the extra overhead for ensuring data integrity.
Our new scheme introduces higher cost at the untrusted worker,
at the price of significantly reducing the cost at the SGX enclave.
The results also demonstrate that, when the input size is not small (i.e.,
greater than 32Ã—\times32),
the new scheme does not increase the cost of the untrusted worker significantly
(i.e., 1.14-1.55 times of the original scheme)
while incurring significantly lower cost at the SGX enclave
(i.e., 0.5%-4.7% of the full-SGX scheme).

S5.T5.caption:
Table V: Backward Propagation Costs for Convolutional Layer
(unit: micro-second): Impact of Input Size.
Settings: sâ€‹tâ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹e=2ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’2stride=2, fâ€‹iâ€‹lâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹zâ€‹e=8â€‹Xâ€‹8ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ_ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’8ğ‘‹8filter\_size=8X8, and fâ€‹iâ€‹lâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹_â€‹nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹bâ€‹eâ€‹r=16ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ_ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ16filter\_number=16.
S5.T5.table:
input size original bwd SGX bwd new bwd selective test
16Ã—\times16 188 398 4611 112
32Ã—\times32 1249 2516 6254 139
64Ã—\times64 6058 12049 13768 191
128Ã—\times128 26771 53107 43840 305
256Ã—\times256 112449 223482 173460 658
references:
TableÂ V shows the costs of the three schemes
for backward propagation through a convolutional layer,
as the size of the input varies from 16Ã—16161616\times 16 to 256Ã—256256256256\times 256.
According to the table,
the full-SGX schemeâ€™s cost (denoted as SGX bwd) is higher than (i.e., about twice of)
the original schemeâ€™s cost (denoted as original bwd),
because the full-SGX scheme needs to load and check the integrity of
the inputs and outputs of the layer.
The new schemeâ€™s cost at the untrusted worker (denoted as new bwd) is also high
because the worker needs to construct large Merkle hash trees
to facilitate selective testing. Specifically,
when the input size is not large (i.e., 32Ã—32323232\times 32 or smaller),
the cost at the worker is as high as 5-24 times of the original schemeâ€™s cost.
However, when the input size becomes larger than 64Ã—64646464\times 64,
the workerâ€™s cost becomes only 1.5-2.3 times of the original schemeâ€™s cost.
Particularly, the workerâ€™s cost is even smaller than the full-SGX schemeâ€™s cost
when the input size is 128Ã—128128128128\times 128 or larger.
The new schemeâ€™s cost at the SGX enclave (denoted as selective test) remains the smallest;
it is 6-28% of the full-SGX schemeâ€™s cost when the input size is no greater than 32Ã—32323232\times 32
and only 0.3-1.6% of the full-SGX schemeâ€™s cost when the input size is 64Ã—64646464\times 64 or larger.
